provenance.note: Possibly acquired, from Blake or John Flaxman or John Linnell, by Thomas Chevalier (1767-1824); possibly Chevalier's great-granddaughter, Ellen M. Chevalier, later Mrs. William Dobinson; possibly sold from her collection, Sotheby's, 1 Dec. 1910, in lot 126 with eight other works (£3 to "Fry," probably acting for the dealer James Tregaskis); the dealer C. A. Stonehill; sold c. 1937 by Stonehill with a group of drawings by Flaxman and his associates to Lessing J. Rosenwald; given by Rosenwald to the National Gallery of Art, Washington, in 1943.

desc.objtitle:
Two Sketches of a Swordsman Standing Over His Defeated Opponent,
object 1 (Butlin 80 verso)

objnote.p: The reference to "Two Sketches" in the title includes a pencil drawing of the same subject and date on the recto.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Near the center of the composition, a standing male(?) figure faces forward yet turns his head left, perhaps to look toward a group of at least three figures standing behind some sort of low horizontal structure near the left edge of the drawing. The central figure wears a long gown with a sash or length of drapery diagonally draped across his chest; the fabric extends over his left shoulder, ending in a serpentine flourish. Pentimenti to the right of this figure suggest he was originally positioned further to the right. He may have long hair, perhaps worn in a braid over his left shoulder, and in his right hand he holds a sword, which is pointed downward to touch the right shoulder of a reclining, defeated figure facing away from the viewer. This male figure appears nude from the waist up and twists his torso to the left with his left arm bent and braced on the ground. Near the right edge of the drawing, a female figure wearing a long gown stands facing away from the viewer and looks left. With both arms bent, she appears to hold or lead the horse at right that also faces left. Between this figure and the horse, there is a shorter figure very faintly drawn who appears to face left with one arm extended backward (perhaps to touch the horse?) and wear a gown. The smaller size of this figure suggests it is a child. Indeterminate horizontal lines in the upper register of the drawing may suggest distant hills.

component.illusobjdesc: Near the center of the composition, a standing male(?) figure faces forward yet turns his head left, perhaps to look toward a group of at least three figures at left. The central figure wears a long gown with a belt and a sash or length of drapery diagonally draped across his chest; the fabric extends over his left shoulder, ending in a serpentine flourish. He may have long hair, perhaps worn in a braid over his left shoulder. His right leg may be crossed behind his left, and in his right hand, he holds a sword, which is pointed downward to touch the right shoulder of a reclining, defeated figure below. Both may be soldiers.
The central standing figure in the drawing holds a sword in his right hand. He points the weapon downward to touch the right shoulder of the figure lying in the lower left corner below him.
Pentimenti to the right of the central standing figure suggest he was originally positioned further to the right.

In the lower left corner of the drawing, a reclining male figure who appears to be defeated (and perhaps a soldier?) lies on his left side and faces away from the viewer. He is nude from the waist up and twists his torso to the left with his left arm bent and braced on the ground. Drapery may cover his legs, which are extended to the right.

Near the right edge of the drawing, a female figure wearing a long gown (with some sort of belt and diagonal sash) stands facing away from the viewer and looks left, perhaps toward the two male figures at left. She appears to have long hair. With both arms bent, she appears to hold or lead the horse at right.
Approximately the front half of a horse with a prominent mane who faces left is visible against the right margin of the drawing.

On the right side of the drawing between the female figure and the horse, there is a shorter figure very faintly drawn who appears to lean right but face left with one arm extended backward (perhaps to touch the horse) and wear a gown. The smaller size of this figure suggests it is a child.
Indeterminate horizontal lines in the upper register of the drawing may suggest distant hills.

A group of at least three figures, each depicted from the waist up, is visible near the upper left corner of the drawing. The leftmost of these faces forward and turns to look slightly right. He(?) appears to have short hair and may wear some sort of gown or drapery. He may look toward the central standing figure who turns left perhaps to meet his gaze.

A group of at least three figures, each depicted from the waist up, is visible near the upper left corner of the drawing. The middle figure faces right to look at its companion at right. This figure may have short hair.

A group of at least three figures, each depicted from the waist up, is visible near the upper left corner of the drawing. The rightmost figure appears to face left and look left toward its companion at left. This figure may have short hair and wear some sort of gown or drapery.
A fourth head, drawn very faintly and directly above the middle figure in the group of three at left, may suggest additional figures in the background.

A diagonal line separating the group of three figures at left from the foreground figures may signify a short wall or other structure. This line appears to continue right of the central figure with a sword.
